name: INTRO TO PROCESS DESIGN

values.comments:
This course is concerned with process synthesis, steady-state simulation, secondlaw
analysis heat integration, cost estimation, profitability analysis, as well as plant-wide
controllability assessment.
Students generally found this course “tedious” and very time consuming.
According to one student the professor sometimes assigns two assignments in one week,
“which makes it difficult to focus on other CBE classes as well.” Overall, students
thought that the class seemed to have “no underlying theme” and that “the course was
fragmented.” Despite these complaints, students found the material itself remained
interesting.
Many students complained about the professor's teaching ability. They were
unhappy that he did not teach modern methods and instead referred to archaic and
obsolete studies and programs. According to one student, “he was un-receptive to
questions and would tell students that their questions were dumb or pointless. In
addition, recitations were not used as a time for students to ask questions but rather as
additional class time where mandatory new information was introduced.” Most thought
that they did not fulfill the goal of the course and “could not honestly say I know
anything about designing a process.”
Many of the students in this course were Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering
upperclassmen. This class was not recommended to either major or non-major students:
according to one student, “overall, a very frustrating course that I wouldn't wish on any
student.”
